Other meat products | num_employees = 2,600 (2016) | homepage = {{URL|www.wlfoods.com}} }} '''West Liberty Foods, [[Limited liability company|L.L.C.]]''' is a US [[meat packing industry|meat processing]] company owned by the Iowa Turkey Growers Cooperative and formed in 1996{{cite news |author = Young, Barbara |title = Growth Essentials. |work = National Provisioner, The |date = May 2004 }} by a group of [[Iowa]] [[Domesticated turkey|turkey]] growers,{{cite news |author = O’Keefe, Terrence |year = 2003 |title = A Slice of the Future |url = http://www.wlfoods.com/0703wp26.pdf |publisher = West Liberty Foods |accessdate = 2006-06-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060329082524/http://www.wlfoods.com/0703wp26.pdf |archivedate = March 29, 2006}} and now owns four meat processing plants.{{cite web|url= http://www.wlfoods.com/about/plants.htm |title=Plants |accessdate=07-05 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070307112647/http://www.wlfoods.com/about/plants.htm |archivedate = March 7, 2007}} The company mainly produces [[Product (business)|products]] for [[customers]] to sell under their own brand names. As of 2006, West liberty Foods was the 12th largest turkey company in the United States.{{cite news |author = O’Keefe, Terrence |url = http://www.wattpoultryusa-digital.com/wattpoultryusa/200702/?pg=64 |title = Top Turkey Company Profiles |work = Watt Poultry USA |date = February 2007 |accessdate = 2007-07-27 }} The company has four facilities in three states. Headquartered in [[West Liberty, Iowa]] the company has a vertically integrated turkey plant in [[West Liberty]] that processes 200 million poundsEstimated fiscal 2014 live weight of live turkeys annually. The company also has manufacturing facilities in [[Mount Pleasant, Iowa]], [[Tremonton, Utah]], and [[Bolingbrook, Illinois]]. The company has over a 400MM pound capacity to further process multiple proteins including turkey, ham, chicken, and beef. While West Liberty Foods has experienced growth and received industry recognition since its inception, it initially faced a difficult market for turkeys, and has experienced problems with labor discontent. [[Employment|Employees]] remain with the company for an average of nine years, with more than 1,500 employed.{{cite news |author = Young, Barbara |title = Extraordinary Chief Executive. |work = National Provisioner, The |date = January 2006}} ==Information== [[File:WL Plant Entrance.JPG|thumb|400px|right|Main entrance to the company’s plant in [[West Liberty, Iowa]]]] The company primarily provides meat for other marketing brands, producing 90% of its product for customers while selling only 10% under the West Liberty Foods brand name. In addition to slaughtering turkeys, the company produces prepared beef, chicken, pork, and turkey products. Company [[revenue]] has grown rapidly with US$65 million in sales during 1997, US$120 million in 2000, and US$200 million in 2003.{{cite web|url= http://www.wlfoods.com/news/meatprocess.html |title=The Iowa Phoenix |accessdate=August 14, 2006 |date=October 2000 |work=Meat Processing |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060329082642/http://www.wlfoods.com/news/meatprocess.html |archivedate = March 29, 2006}} Most recently, West Liberty Foods posted US$442 million in revenue for 2006, making the company the 56th largest meat packing company by sales in the United States.{{cite news |author = Gazdziak, Sam |title = The National Provisioner's Top 125. |work = National Provisioner, The |page = 56 |date = May 2006}} Much of the company's sales come from large nationwide [[foodservice]] customers, and, as of 2006, was [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]]'s largest supplier of sliced sandwich meat, providing the [[franchising|franchise]] with more than 1 million pounds per week. As a result of servicing national customers, the company is inspected more than other food manufacturers.{{cite web|url=http://www.wlfoods.com/news/iowa-gr.htm |title= West Liberty Foods Finds Success with Cooperation |accessdate=August 14, 2006 |year=2006 |work=Iowa Grocer |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060329082713/http://www.wlfoods.com/news/iowa-gr.htm |archivedate = March 29, 2006}} West Liberty Foods' three plants have been [[ISO 14000|ISO 14001]] certified for meeting environmental management standards, and the West Liberty plant was the first turkey processing plant in the United States to receive this [[Professional certification|certification]].{{cite web|url= http://www.wlfoods.com/about/environment.htm |title=Environment |accessdate=August 14, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060618232122/http://wlfoods.com/about/environment.htm |archivedate = June 18, 2006}} West Liberty Foods maintains separate facilities for [[research and development]] and laboratory [[Experiment|testing]] services. They are housed in adjacent buildings several blocks from the plant in West Liberty. The R&D facility includes testing space for both [[raw food|raw]] and cooked product, and can create test products from start to finish, including initial formulation, final slicing, and [[Packaging and labelling|packaging]]. The lab conducts product quality testing for the three production facilities and uses [[polymerase chain reaction]] (PCR) technology for rapid bacteriological testing.{{cite news |author = Bagel, Ann |title = Food Safety First |work = Poultry |page = 16 |date = Apr–May 2005 }} This system can return results within 30 hours of production. ==History== Prior to 1996, [[Oscar Mayer|Louis Rich]], the brand name for [[Oscar Mayer]]'s turkey [[Division (organisation)|division]], owned the processing plant in West Liberty, IA. In early 1996, Oscar Mayer's parent company, [[Kraft Foods]], announced that they would close the plant that December if no buyer purchased it. The Iowa turkey growers who sold to Kraft discussed purchasing the plant to ensure that [[Supply and demand|demand]] for their birds remained. In May 1996, forty-seven of the turkey growers formed the Iowa Turkey Growers Cooperative(ITGC). ITGC purchased the plant from Kraft and took control of it in December. The growers hired meat industry veteran Ken Rutledge to be President and COO of the company.{{cite web|url= http://www.wlfoods.com/news/niche.html |title=Finding the Right Niche |accessdate=August 14, 2006 |date=October 2006 |work=Meat Processing |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060329082721/http://www.wlfoods.com/news/niche.html |archivedate = March 29, 2006}} Oscar Mayer helped West Liberty Foods by promising to purchase half of the plant's output in 1997 and a quarter of the output in 1998 to help the [[startup company]].{{cite news | author =Associated Press | title =Low Prices Hurt Turkey Co-Op | work =Telegraph Herald | page =A5 | date =December 15, 1997 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb Production under ITGC ownership began in January 1997. The company faced financial difficulty because the turkey market was oversupplied and prices hit historic lows. While financial projections assumed a price of US$1.92 per pound for turkey, prices averaged US$1.46 per pound in 1997. During this time period, four of the growers left ITGC. Turkey prices eventually rebounded, and the company was bolstered by sales to [[Sara Lee (corporation)|Sara Lee]] near the end of 1998. Since the rebound, West Liberty Foods’ sales have grown steadily. In 2000, the company acquired a second plant in Sigourney, IA from [[Pinnacle Foods]] to meet rising [[Order (business)|orders]].The facility was sold in 2012. The company grew again in April 2003 when it opened a processing plant in Mount Pleasant, IA which was later expanded in 2004.{{cite news |author = Young, Barbara |title = Branding Food Safety. |work = National Provisioner, The |date = May 2004}} Company leadership changed in 2004 as Ed Garrett was named president and COO when Rutledge resigned to take a position with another growers' organization.{{cite news |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=11094778&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = Change at the Top of WL Foods |work = West Liberty Index |date = March 9, 2004 | accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} In 2006 the company entered into a marketing alliance agreement with [[Midvale, Utah]] based [[Norbest Foods]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wlfoods.com/about/news.htm |title=News and Press Releases http |accessdate=August 14, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060618231756/http://wlfoods.com/about/news.htm |archivedate = June 18, 2006}} ==Labor episode== In 2004, [[Labour (economics)|workers]] at the West Liberty plant considered joining the [[United Food and Commercial Workers|United Food and Commercial Workers International Union]] (UFCW).{{cite news |author = Ervin, Stacy |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=12235105&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = West Liberty Foods Vote in Limbo |work = West Liberty Index |date = July 6, 2004 |accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} On July 1, 2004 the workers voted on whether they would be represented by UFCW Local 431. An initial tally of votes came out 301 in favor and 299 against [[trade union|union]] representation. However, the count did not include 13 ballots which were disputed by UFCW. The ballots were challenged on claims that they were cast by management personnel who would not be union members. A [[National Labor Relations Board]] (NLRB) hearing to confirm or invalidate the vote was scheduled for January 5, 2005 but then postponed until February 16, 2005.{{cite news |author = Konrad, Sara |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=13726507&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = West Liberty Foods Hearing Postponed |work = West Liberty Index |date = January 11, 2005 |accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} On February 1, 2005 the company and UFCW settled their dispute.{{cite news |author = Konrad, Sara |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=14011552&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = WL Foods, Labor Union Reach Settlement |work = West Liberty Index |date = February 22, 2005 |accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} UFCW withdrew its objections, and West Liberty Foods posted a [[notice]] that they would not close the plant or fire workers if employees unionized. This resulted in a final vote count of 303 to 308 against union representation. UFCW Local 431 held a second vote at the West Liberty plant on July 15, 2005.{{cite news |author = Becker, Sarah |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=14883933&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = Workers Vote Down Union |work = West Liberty Index |date = July 19, 2005 |accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} The vote was 231 to 322 against unionization. In 2009, the company paid US$58,613.75 to Labor Information Services, an anti-union management services company connected to [[The Burke Group]], to provide consultants who met directly with workers "either individually or in group meetings...regarding union issues."{{Cite OLMS|filenum=C-0464|rptId=414246|rptForm=LM21Form|date=February 25, 2010}} ==Plants== [[File:WLF Plants.jpg|frame|right|Locations of the three West Liberty Foods plants in Iowa]] West Liberty Foods' three plants combined can convert 4.5 million turkeys into product annually. This equals approximately 180 million pounds of product per year. ===West Liberty plant=== The West Liberty Plant is a {{convert|270000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility which slaughters and further processes turkey products. The slaughter operation converts approximately 20,000 turkeys per [[Working time|workday]].{{cite news | first =Jerry | last =Perkins | title =West Liberty Foods packs in success | work =Des Moines Register, The | page =1M | date =May 22, 2005 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb Louis H. Rich, purchased the West Liberty plant, a former tomato canning facility, in 1943, when he decided to expand the operations of the Rock Island Produce Company, located on 9th Street in [[Rock Island, Illinois]]. The plant was converted to a poultry, including chickens and turkeys, slaughter facility in 1946 and refocused by Rich's sons, Norman and Martin, on turkey in 1949. The plant was first expanded in 1960. Oscar Mayer acquired the plant, through its purchase of Louis Rich, Inc., in 1979 and used it for turkey production until selling the plant in 1996. ===Mount Pleasant plant=== The Mount Pleasant plant is a {{convert|85000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} facility that is used for slicing cooked cheese, turkey, chicken, beef, pork and other products. The plant employs approximately 500 people working in three shifts. A {{convert|68000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Millard Refrigerated Services facility is located adjacent to the Mount Pleasant plant. The two facilities are connected, and product is immediately transferred by [[Conveyor belt|conveyor]] from the plant to cold storage when packaging is complete. The design and operation of the Mount Pleasant plant to are intended decrease potential hazards to food safety.{{cite news |author = Lazar, Virginia |title = Listeria Benchmark: 0 |work = Meat Processing |page = 26 |date = November 2003}} WLF representatives have stated that the goal of the Mount Pleasant plant is to create a [[pathogen]]-free environment. Because company officials believe that the food safety aspects of the plant are unique in the meat industry, they submitted the plant design for patent approval through the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent Office]]. The Mount Pleasant plant is located approximately {{convert|50|mi|km}} from either the West Liberty or Sigourney plants. This reduces the likelihood that pathogens will be carried either by air or foot traffic from a raw production area to Mount Pleasant's ready to eat production. The Mount Pleasant facility consists of approximately 20 individual processing cells that are separated from one another and are set up so that they could operate as individual meat slicing facilities. Before anti-microbial [[flooring]] was poured, the cells were erected with [[stainless steel]] [[Antimicrobial|anti-microbial]] walls that are built into the floor. Each processing cell has independent refrigeration and [[drainage]] systems. The refrigeration systems [[Air filter|filter]] the cell's air and maintain positive [[Pressure|air pressure]] at {{convert|38|°F|°C|abbr=on}}, and the drainage systems are sealed off and flooded with sanitizers nightly. During operation, fully cooked meat or cheese logs arrive sealed in impermeable [[Casing (sausage)|casings]]. The logs go through a casing sanitation step that involves being treated with a sanitizing liquid before the casings are removed from the logs. The logs then undergo a post-lethality treatment by passing through an [[infrared]] [[pasteurization]] tunnel to kill pathogens on the logs. The logs are then mechanically transferred to slicers, sliced, and placed in sealed packages that are transferred out of the processing cell. The mechanical transfers decrease the risk of product contamination by reducing handling of product by personnel . Food safety is a factor in hiring employees at the Mount Pleasant facility. Before applying, potential employees must complete a 16-hour food safety training course through [[Iowa State University]]. The class includes written tests which each applicant must pass before completing the course. On the job, employees must don a sealed [[clean room suit]] before entering slicing cells. The suits are cleaned and sealed in a [[clean room]] laundry facility in [[North Carolina]] by the uniform company [[Cintas]]. Employees replace the clean suit each time they leave the cell so each employee averages five suits per day. ===Sigourney plant=== The Sigourney plant is no longer active, and has been closed. The remaining employees were released as of Wed. March 18, 2009. West Liberty sold the facility in 2012. ===Tremonton, Utah plant=== As of 2006, West Liberty Foods plans to build a plant in [[Tremonton, Utah]].{{cite news | first =Brice | last =Wallace |author2=Anderton, Dave | title =Meat processor opts for move to Box Elder | work =Deseret News, The | page =D12 | date =July 29, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb The plant will not slaughter, but the {{convert|200000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} facility{{cite news | title =A New Facility Arises in Utah: West Liberty Foods is building the world's most advanced meat-processing facility, not in Iowa, but out West. | work =Co-Packing Solutions | publisher =Stagnito Communications | pages =4–5 | date =June 2007 }} will allot {{convert|93000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} for processing and {{convert|74000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} for slicing a variety of meat products. The company broke ground for the facility in October 2006. It is expected to begin production in July 2007. When completed, the plant will be the first in North America to slice {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} slicing logs.{{cite news | first =George | last =Ford | title =W. Liberty Foods selects plant site | work =Gazette, The | page =9B | date =July 29, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb The plant will initially have ten slicing cells allowing production of 150 million pounds per year and will eventually add ten more cells to double the plant's capaicty. At full capacity, the plant will employ more than 500 people.{{cite news | first =Blake | last =Deborah | title =West Liberty Foods confirms Tremonton plant deal | work =Standard-Examiner | date =July 29, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb Similar to the Mount Pleasant plant, a {{convert|50000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} Millard Refrigerated Services facility will be built adjacent to the Tremonton plant for warehouse storage of refrigerated and frozen products. Initially, the company investigated sites for the new plant in [[Utah]], [[Nevada]], and [[Arizona]].{{cite news | first =Lesley | last =Mitchell | title =Meat-processing plant to employ 500 in Utah | work =Salt Lake Tribune | date =April 21, 2006 | accessdate = 2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb It requested US$5.2 million in tax incentives Utah to build in [[Pleasant View, Utah]]. On April 26, 2006 Utah's Department of Community and Economic Development approved a US$2 million tax-rebate over 10 years.{{cite news | first =Charles | last =Trentelman | title =Incentives OK'd to lure meat plant | work =Standard-Examiner | date =April 27, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb The incentives were conditioned on the new jobs paying a certain level above the county median wage, offering health insurance, and the company staying in Utah for 10 years. Pleasant View offered another US$1.4-US$1.8 million in incentives. However, construction in Pleasant View became impossible when it was discovered that much of the site consisted of wetland areas.{{cite news | first =Charles | last =Trentelman | title =Wetlands scuttle plans for meat plant | work =Standard-Examiner | date =April 10, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb After this development, the state held the incentive offer open provided that West Liberty Foods could find another suitable site that met Utah's requirements.{{cite news | first =Mitchell | last =Lesley | title =Incentives that were offered to West Liberty may still be an option, recruiting office says | work =Salt Lake Tribune | date =May 9, 2006 | accessdate =2006-07-31 }}, cited at Newsbank/Infoweb On July 29, 2006, the company announced that they would build the new plant in Tremonton, Utah. The tax incentives will total an 80% property tax break, but Tremonton is projected to experience a US$508 thousand financial benefit over 12 years after the plant is completed. Of the 500 jobs at the plant, 300 are expected to pay between US$21,500 and US$26,875. The rest of the jobs will pay more with about 100 paying around US$37,000. ==Awards== West Liberty Foods has received a number of awards from various organizations. * 2001 – Subway Supplier of the Year * 2003 – Paul Hill honored by the National Council of Farmer Cooperatives * 2005 – Economic Vision Award from [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] Rural Development,{{cite news |url = http://www.zwire.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=1196827&BRD=1105&PAG=461&dept_id=151632&rfi=8 |title = West Liberty Foods Receives Venture Award |work = West Liberty Index |date = December 20, 2000 |accessdate = 2006-06-14 }} Best Business [[Recycling]] Program award from Iowa Recycling Association, Dedicated Services Award from Subway * 2006 – Ed Garrett named "Executive of the Year" by The National Provisioner, Mount Pleasant and Sigourney plants receive Safety Awards from Iowa-Illinois Safety Council, a chapter of the [[National Safety Council]] * 2007 – Quality Gold Standard Award from Subway [[Hormel]] Spirit of Excellence Award in 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, and 2002. * 2008 – Subway Supply Chain Partner Award – Iowa-Illinois Safety Council Safety Award -Food Quality Award ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Agriculture companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Iowa]] [[Category:Cooperatives in the United States]] [[Category:Brand name poultry meats]] [[Category:Companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Meat processing in the United States]]
